Chapter Two Hundred and Ninety-Two: Concerning the Knowledge of the Station of the Shared Realm of the Unseen (عالم الغيب) and the Visible (عالم الشهادة) from the Mosaic Presence (الحضرة الموسوية)

The night conceals the wonder that is in the Unseen,
And the Sun reveals what the darkness conceals.

And the person, if feminine, does not mention it,
Until the other (feminine) comes and reminds her of it.

Generosity (الجود) is the origin, and the opposite of Generosity has no
Origin, but the very Essence of Generosity manifests it.

Nothing enriches you save Allah, so be content with Him
As Lord, and do not be among those who conceal Him.

Stand by Him in knowledge upon the peak of a hill,
And if you witness a crescent moon, He makes it full.

And if passion (الهوى) calls you one day to deficiency,
Then its caller (the Divine) will restrain it from that.

His giving is from Him, first and last,
And it is not in exchange (عوض); thus I mention it.
Indeed, recompense (الجزاء) is conformity, not based on exchange,
For if it were an exchange, I would not prefer it.

### [The Specificity of the Station of the Realm of the Unseen and the Visible to the Knowledge of the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) Likened to the Sun]

Peace be upon you, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings. Know, O our brethren, that this station (منزل) is one of the greatest in rank. It is the station of the Unseen Marriage (النكاح الغيبي), which is the marriage of meanings (المعاني) and spirits (الأرواح). The knowledge of the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) likened to the Sun—with no cloud beneath it—is specific to this station, unlike the lunar theophany of the full moon. The latter is referred to in the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "You will see your Lord as you see the moon on the night of the full moon."

That lunar theophany has no entry into this station.

[This station is characterized by the vision] "as you see the sun at noon, with no cloud beneath it."

This station is its place, and from here it is known. It is a wondrous Divine manifestation (مظهر إلهي عجيب). From this station is known: Generosity (الجود) constrained by fear and recompense; the rank of truthfulness (الصدق) even if it appears ugly; the rank of falsehood (الكذب) even if it appears beautiful; acquired wealth (الغني المكتسب), which is accidental wealth; the signs of felicity (السعادة) and the signs of misery (الشقاء); the failure of one who relies upon matters that Allah has established for reliance, and why the reliant person fails despite the Real (الحق) having established those matters for this purpose and qualified their people for it; the science of clarifying the degrees of Divine Proximity (التقريب الإلهي) from the Presence of the Tongue (حضرة اللسن); the knowledge of the station where the two co-wives (الضرتان) reconcile and love each other; the knowledge of the necessary Rapture (الاصطلام اللازم); the description of those among the near ones (المقربين) who are granted this station of Rapture, as opposed to those like them who are not; and Generosity (الجود) with what the Gnostic (العارف) finds of everything that is not obligatory upon him, which is the character of Divine Generosity. [Also known is] whether the Real (الحق) can be an exchange (عوض) attained through a specific deed or not. We shall explain the realities of this station, chapter by chapter, through allusion and suggestion, for it is lengthy. Allah is the Supporter, there is no Lord but Him.

Among these matters is the productive Unseen Marriage (النكاح الغيبي). Allah the Exalted said: <<وَأَرْسَلْنَا الرِّيَاحَ لَوَاقِحَ>> (And We sent the fertilizing winds). And He the Exalted said: <<وَأَنْزَلَ مِنَ السَّمَاءِ مَاءً فَأَخْرَجَ بِهِ مِنَ الثَّمَرَاتِ>> (And He sent down water from the heaven and brought forth thereby fruits). And He said: <<جَعَلَ لَكُمُ الْأَرْضَ فِرَاشًا وَالسَّمَاءَ بِنَاءً>> (He made the earth a resting place for you and the heaven a canopy). We have previously discussed this section in the chapter on Gnosis (المعارف) in this book, in the chapter on the Celestial Fathers and the Terrestrial Mothers, so let it be reviewed there.

In this station, we mention what relates to it, which is that meanings (المعاني) marry bodies (الأجسام) in an unseen, spiritual marriage, and their effects (أحكامهما) are generated between them. This is a veil over the unseen Divine Hand, whose nature is not to be perceived. From this [marriage] are all the forms (الصور) that appear in the Primordial Dust (الهباء). The Primordial Dust is like the wife to the forms, and the forms are like the husband to the Dust. Nothing is produced from them except their Immutable Essences (أعيانهما). This is one of the most wondrous secrets: that the child is the very essence (عين) of the father and mother for whom it is a child, and the father and mother are the very essence of the child for whom they are parents. This is what Al-Hallaj, may Allah have mercy on him, alluded to in his saying: "My mother gave birth to her father." The parent is the very essence of the child for whom he is a parent and the child is his offspring only in this marriage.

From this chapter is His saying: "Be!" (كُنْ), which is the word of formation (أمر التكوين). He said concerning Jesus that he is the Word of Allah, and concerning the existents that they are the Words of Allah. He has no word in the existents except "Be!" (كُنْ), and it is the very essence of the existent (عين الموجود), for it is the Word. Its direction is toward the Fixed Entities (العيون الثابتة), and the Essences are like the mother to it. Thus, the Words appeared, which is the existence of those Essences resulting from this Unseen Marriage. The child between them was their very essence, nothing else. This is subtler than the first matter, for the child here is the very essence of the Word of the Presence. "Be!" (كُنْ) is the very essence of the Formed (المكون), and it is attributed to Allah. The first [marriage] is in the second degree, for it is attributed to the Primordial Dust (الهباء) and the form. This marriage is integrated into it, so understand, for I have set you upon the path.

All corporeal things (الجسمانيات) are offspring of an unseen marriage. All bodies are either from a purely unseen marriage, or from an unseen marriage integrated into a sensory marriage, such as the marriage of winds and waters, animals, plants, minerals, and what is generated in the elemental bodies (الأجسام العنصرية), but not the natural bodies. The mundane world (العالم الملكي) does not generate anything of its own kind, unless it acts as a father at a certain time to an elemental mother by what it casts into her. What is produced is the child between them, which may be created as an angel. This is what is expressed as the "angelic impulse" (لمة الملك), which is what the angel casts into the human soul (النفس الإنسانية). A glorification (تسبيحة) or a declaration of unity (تهليلة) is generated between them, issuing from the breath of the one glorifying or declaring unity. A kingly form (صورة ملكية) opens up in the essence and substance of that breath, with the casting angel as its father and the soul as its mother. That form ascends to its father and remains attached to him, seeking forgiveness for its mother, the human soul, until the Day of Resurrection. From this, the ruling in the Sacred Law (الشريعة) is derived, allowing the father to take his child from the mother when the child reaches discernment and intellect, without dispute, for this angel is created rational.

Among the most wondrous marriages is Non-Existence (الإعدام), and for this reason, the people of Unveiling (أهل الكشف) differed concerning it. Allah the Glorious linked it to the Will (المشيئة), saying: <<إِنْ يَشَأْ يُذْهِبْكُمْ>> (If He wills, He can remove you). And He linked Power (الاقتدار) to the creation of other people, saying: <<وَيَأْتِ بِآخَرِينَ>> (And bring others). And Allah was capable of that, and He did not say "those two" in the dual form. The allusion was, by virtue of His Oneness (أحديتها), to the nearest, which is what He brought forth.

From this chapter is the sending of the Barren Wind (الريح العقيم), for it is meant to remove the essences of the manifest forms (أعيان الصور الظاهرة) from composition, not the essences of the substances (أعيان الجواهر). Since it produced no existence, barrenness was attributed to it, and it was negated from being fertilizing. This is a marriage purely for desire (الشهوة), not for the existence of offspring, like the marriage of the people of Paradise. Not every desire results in a substantial existence for itself.

From here arose the disagreement among the people of Unveiling. Those whose unveiling showed the return of the existent forms to their immutable, non-existent state (ثابتة غير موجودة) said that the Barren Wind did produce in the Presence of Immutability (حضرة الثبوت) what had departed from it, and this is witnessed by the Real (الحق). To this relates the Will in His saying: <<إِنْ يَشَأْ يُذْهِبْكُمْ>> (If He wills, He can remove you), meaning, return you to the state in which you were described by non-existence (العدم). This was barrenness because no existence of the essence for itself appeared from it, even though it was manifest and witnessed by its Creator.

Those who did not witness the return of the essences of the existent forms to non-existence upon the direction of the Will or the blowing of the Barren Wind said that it produces nothing, for creation (الإيجاد) is for Power (الاقتدار), not for Will alone, and it is for the fertilizing wind, not the barren one. If anything existent appeared from it, it would not be barren. This is the cause of the disagreement among the people of Unveiling: the concern of the denier is the eye of existence (عين الوجود), and the concern of the affirmant is the eye of immutability (عين الثبوت). Since they do not refer to the same thing, there is no real disagreement. For us, the realized ones (المحققين), disagreement is inconceivable on this path, unless it is of this nature, which is a verbal disagreement (خلاف لفظي). If each explains what he intended by that word, the disagreement is lifted. What we have alluded to is sufficient.

### [The Variation of Manifestations According to Stations]

From this station is the Solar Theophany (التجلي الشمسي), because the similitude used by the scholars of external forms (علماء الرسوم) to remove doubt from the viewer regarding the object of vision was the sun and the moon on the night of the full moon. This is one of the intended aspects of that Hadith. However, the realized ones (المحققون) know, in addition to this, that the two manifestations (المظهرين) are different. The theophany likened to the moon on the night of the full moon is a specific manifestation (مظهر خاص), because the Prophet said "on the night of the full moon" and did not say "in its fullness," thus attributing it to the night. I witness it as full even when the sun is present during the day. He attributed it to the night only for a reason known to the realized ones, but this is not the station for discussing it.

However, this station includes the station of the Theophany in the Sun. For the Real (الحق), according to the realized ones, is too exalted to manifest in one form twice or to two persons. There is no repetition in any matter concerning the Real, due to the Absolute (الإطلاق) nature He possesses and the Divine Vastness (الاتساع الإلهي). Repetition leads to constraint and limitation.

Know that the Solar Theophany—that is, the one likened to the sun—is called by us the Wider Theophany (التجلي الأوسع). It is the theophany in which the human does not perish from seeing himself within it. We alluded to this at the beginning of this book in the chapter on the earth created from the remainder of the Adamic clay. This Theophany is a wondrous essential manifestation (مظهر ذاتي عجيب). The Theophany in it is attributed to its effect (معلوله) and not to its cause (علته), even though the cause appears in its effect as a verified essence (عينا محققة) of unknown modality (مجهولة الكيفية), like the appearance of the sun in the day, even though the day is an effect of the sun's appearance, or the light of a lamp from the lamp spreading into the corners of the cosmos. Such a vision is called the witnessing of the cause and its effect together.

Every theophany that does not make you independent of yourself is of this nature. It is called Wider (أوسع) because the observer's vision encompasses the Self-discloser (المتجلي), the medium in which the disclosure occurs (المتجلي فيه), and himself (له). The non-wider theophany causes you to witness nothing else—neither yourself nor others—nor do you know your witnessing or the state you are in until you return to yourself and the veil (الحجاب) falls. If the veil were permanent, that theophany would be constrained and narrow, as the veil would limit it. The Wider Theophany appears in the veil and outside the veil, and the witness distinguishes between the two forms. For this reason, it is said of them, "Return them to their palaces," alluding to their incapacity, meaning they are confined therein.

Here are oceans containing types of precious jewels that only every wide-souled diver, passionately in love with the Unseen, can perceive. I have explained to you the purpose of this Theophany contained within this station. Its benefits are countless; if we were to mention them, no register could contain them. It has perpetuity in the higher world (العالم العلوي) in this life, and perpetuity in the lower world (العالم الأخروي السفلي) in the Hereafter. There is no theophany that combines opposites in its effects—such as pain and pleasure—except this Theophany. It is like the manifestation of the Beloved to the lover while the Beloved embraces and kisses another. The lover is in pleasure from his gaze [upon the Beloved] and in pain from his gaze [upon the other].

From this station is the knowledge of Generosity (الجود) constrained by fear and recompense, the rank of truthfulness (الصدق) even if it appears ugly, the rank of falsehood (الكذب) even if it appears beautiful, acquired wealth (الغني المكتسب), which is accidental wealth, and the signs of felicity and the signs of misery.

### [The Variation of the Cause of Giving]

Know that the causes of giving (العطاء) vary. Some give for exchange (العوض), which is called buying and selling. There is generosity in it, in that the buyer has been graced by you, the seller, since he has a great purpose in obtaining it, and he has given you what he is independent of. Thus, each has shown generosity (جاد) to his companion by delivering to him what he had a purpose in obtaining, since he had the power to withhold it. To this extent, it is included in the chapter of Generosity from the perspective of the recipient (اسم مفعول), but not from the perspective of the giver (اسم فاعل).

A person may also give in this chapter out of fear for his honor or the onset of sensory pains that afflict him. It is as if he buys good praise, well-being, and security with that giving. This is like the first case, but the difference is that what was bought in the first case is something in which he might have a purpose, whereas in pain, the removal of well-being, and security, he can have no purpose whatsoever.

As for those among our companions who say otherwise, if they are realized ones, like Abu Yazid in his saying:

> All my desires I have attained,
> Except the pleasurable ecstasy of my torment.

He has clarified his intention, which is pleasure (اللذة), and this is what we have said and adopted. If he is not a realized one, then he is not fundamentally on our path, even if he appears so externally, and we have no discussion with him.

Some give for grace (الإنعام) and other reasons, but only what we have mentioned specifically belongs to this station. From this chapter is the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "Love Allah for the graces (نعم) He nourishes you with."

He commanded us to love Him for His grace and beneficence. Does any existent matter from Him concerning the servants fall outside of grace (الإنعام) in any way? Our companions differed on this. Some held that grace is the very essence of existence (عين وجوده), and they do not pay attention to the related purposes. The ruling of this existent being, graced with existence, is that He has graced the pain (الألم) with the existence of its essence, even if the one afflicted by it does not agree with his purpose. It is Allah's grace upon Himself. If the matter depended on the universality of grace upon everyone through a single essence, nothing would exist at all, for realities reject that.

Thus, He has grace in every existence. The one whose station is altruism (الإيثار) is truthful in his purpose by his asceticism (زهده) if the ruling of pain afflicts him, in that he thanks Allah for the existence of the pain's essence after it was non-existent. This is preferring the Divine Presence (جناب الله) over his own purpose, since there appeared in the cosmos one who assists him in magnifying and thanking Allah, because he witnesses the pain thanking Allah the Exalted for creating its essence. The greatest intercessor (شفيع) for one in this state before Allah is the pain among the existents, and the Name *Al-Mubli* (The Afflicter) and *Al-Musqim* (The One Who Causes Sickness) among the Divine Names. The result of that intercession is the existence of pleasure (اللذة) and the departure of pain, either by the removal of its cause or by its remaining, which would be a breaking of habit (خرق عادة). This is one of the greatest characters by which a human is honored.

As for his altruism in this matter for the sake of Allah's Will, no one knows the good that accrues to him from the Name *Al-Murīd* (The Willer) except Allah, who has singled him out for this noble state. This is truthfulness (الصدق) in dealing with Allah, even if it appears ugly. If that pain were to descend upon someone else, this state would necessarily accompany him. It would be ugly for him, concerning the other person, to see him thanking Allah for the pain that afflicted that other, especially if the other were beloved to him, or a prophet or messenger. However, what this station produces—the existence of well-being (العافية) in that other—veils the ugliness that this realized one had worn.

As for the one who refrains from giving in a situation like the one we mentioned, you know from what we have explained the reason for that refraining and what the refrainer witnesses at the time of refraining. The knowledge of all that is integrated into what we have established, so search for it, for it would be lengthy if we were to detail it. We have given you the key and specified its lock, so open whatever you wish of it.

As for acquired wealth (الغني المكتسب) in this chapter, it is its ruling. If a person becomes independent of others, it is evidence of his ignorance of realities, since the other has no effect on him. He has linked his independence to something that has no link. If he becomes independent of Allah the Exalted, he is even more ignorant, for by this description he has departed from verified knowledge (العلم المحقق) and from Islam. There is no one more lost than him, because there is no one more ignorant than him.

True independence (الاستغناء) is not genuinely valid. Therefore, if wealth is attributed to anyone, it is an accidental attribution (إضافة عرضية), not essential. For this reason, the Name *Al-Ghanī* (The Rich) for the Real (الحق) the Exalted is a negative attribute (صفة سلبي), negating His need for the world. Whoever needs something is never independent of it.

True independence is only through means (الأسباب) in terms of relationships (النسب). Every relationship that removes its opposite is the one that governs you. Whether it is called wealth or not is up to your consideration, according to what the reality of that relationship grants you. If it makes you independent of others, then it is wealth, and you are wealthy by it. If it does not make you independent, then it is not wealth, and you are not wealthy by it.

Satiety (الشبع), for example, by its mere reality, is not said to make you independent of hunger (الجوع) in terms of the reality of hunger, because hunger is not sought by you so that you might become independent of it through satiety. However, if hunger, when it afflicts you, grants you purity (الصفاء), subtlety (الرقة), refinement (اللطافة), and realization of servitude (العبودة) and neediness (الافتقار)—which is what its reality grants—then you seek it and are not independent of it. If satiety grants you what hunger grants you of all that we mentioned, then you have become independent of hunger, since hunger is not sought for itself, but is sought for what we mentioned. If we find that in its opposite, we have no need for it, as nature rejects it, just as nature produces it.

For this reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sought refuge from hunger and said, "It is a bad companion."

This is because, even though it grants what we mentioned, it does not guarantee that the neediness is directed toward Allah; rather, it may be directed toward something other than Allah. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, called it a "bad companion" generally. The masters of the Path say that if hunger were sold in the market, the seeker (المريد) would be obliged to buy it. But whoever views it as the Prophet viewed it considers it among the errors of the people of the Path, like Abu Abd al-Rahman al-Sulami, who compiled papers on the errors of the Sufis—and this is our doctrine. Hunger has a limit and measure, which is verified hunger (الجوع المحقق), unlike imagined hunger. The Prophetic seeking of refuge was only from verified hunger, for by it a person becomes disobedient to the Law (الشرع) and unjust to himself if it is by choice. For this reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, never went hungry except out of necessity, which is the state of the scholars of Allah, because justice is their attribute.

I have clarified what is sufficient for you, for it is an allusion that suffices for explicit statement.

### [The Sign of the Deed of Felicity is that the Human is Employed in Presence with Allah]

As for the deeds of felicity (أعمال السعادة), their signs are that the human is employed in the Presence (الحضور) with Allah in all his movements and possibilities, and that he witnesses the attribution of acts to Allah the Exalted in terms of creation and the praiseworthy connection. As for the blameworthy connection, if he attributes it to Allah, he has shown bad manners and is ignorant of the science of obligation (علم التكليف) and to whom the obligation is directed, and who the obligated one is who was told "Do!" If the obligated one had no connection to the act whatsoever, he would not have been told "Do!" and the entire Sacred Law would be futile, yet it is true in itself.

Therefore, the servant must have a correct connection (نسبة صحيحة) to the act, and it is because of that connection that he is told "Do!" Its connection is not the Will (الإرادة), as those who speak of acquisition (الكسب) claim, but rather it is a subtle power-cause (سبب اقتداري لطيف) integrated into the Divine Power (الاقتدار الإلهي) that the humble one grants, like the integration of the light of the stars into the light of the sun. You know by reason (الدليل) that the stars have light spread upon the earth, but we do not perceive it sensually due to the dominance of the sun's light. Similarly, the senses perceive that the acts of the servants belong to them sensually and legally, but the Divine Power is integrated into it, perceived by the intellect (العقل) but not by the senses, like the integration of the sun's light into the light of the stars. The light of the stars is the very essence of the sun's light, and the stars are merely a medium of manifestation (مجلى). The entire light is the sun, yet the senses attribute the light to the stars, saying the light of the stars is integrated into the light of the sun. In reality, there is only the light of the sun, so its light is integrated into itself, since there is no other light there.

Although mirrors have an effect, that effect is not from their own light. Light has one effect when it is in the cosmos without an intermediary, and it has another effect in the mirror of its theophany (مرآة تجليه) by a ruling that differs from its ruling without that intermediary. When the sun's light manifests in the full moon (البدر), it grants rulings that it does not grant without the full moon; there is no doubt about this. Similarly, when the Divine Power manifests in the servants, and acts appear from creation, even though it is by Divine Power, the ruling differs because of the mediation of this medium of manifestation (مجلى) which was like a mirror for His Theophany. Just as the solar light is attributed to the full moon sensually and functionally, even though the light belongs to the sun, so too is the act attributed to creation sensually, while the act belongs to Allah in reality. Due to the difference in effect, the luminous ruling (الحكم النوري) changes in things. Thus, what the light grants through the mediation of the full moon differs from what it grants by itself without mediation. Similarly, the ruling differs in the acts of the servants.

From here is known upon whom the obligation (التكليف) is directed and to whom it is connected. Just as you know intellectually that the moon itself contains none of the sun's light, and that the sun has not transferred to it in its essence, but rather the moon is a medium of manifestation for it, and that the attribute does not depart from its possessor and the Name from its named, similarly, the servant contains nothing of his Creator, nor has He indwelt him; rather, the servant is merely a medium of manifestation (مجلى) and a locus of appearance (مظهر) for Him. Just as the sun's light is attributed to the moon, so too is Power attributed to creation sensually, and the state is the state.

If the matter between the sun and the moon is of this nature, despite its subtlety, and not everyone knows it, then what do you think of the Divine matter concerning creation in this issue? It is subtler and subtler. Whoever grasps this knowledge possesses one of the highest signs of felicity. The loss of such knowledge is a sign of misery. By this, I mean the spiritual felicity and misery of the souls. As for sensory felicity and misery, their signs are the prescribed deeds (الأعمال المشروعة) performed with their conditions, which is sincerity (الإخلاص). Allah the Exalted said: <<أَلَا لِلَّهِ الدِّينُ الْخَالِصُ>> (Unquestionably, to Allah belongs the pure religion). And He said: <<وَمَا أُمِرُوا إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُوا اللَّهَ مُخْلِصِينَ>> (And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, dedicating the religion to Him). This much is sufficient for the signs in summary. Allah is the Granter of success, there is no Lord but Him.

### [Concerning the Failure of One Who Relies Upon Matters that Allah Has Established for Reliance]

As for the failure of one who relies upon matters that Allah has established for reliance, and why the reliant person fails despite the Real (الحق) having established those matters for this purpose and qualified their people for it: Know, O noble brother, that the matters which the Real established for reliance have not departed from Him. However, this failed person made them lords (أربابا) besides Allah, relying upon their essences (ذواتها) and not upon the One who established them. Thus, ignorance (الجهل) struck him, as we mentioned earlier.

If the observer looks at the effects appearing from the sun's light in the mirror of the full moon and relies upon the sun in that, by virtue of this specific medium of manifestation (مجلى) to which Allah linked the effect, then this person will not fail. He has given the matter its due. The moon will never be eclipsed for him. The one who fails is the one for whom the moon is eclipsed, so he remains in the darkness of his ignorance (ظلمة جهله) despite the existence of the lunar mirror's essence. This failed person is in darkness with that manifestation, for the moon has been veiled concerning this person who relied upon it. <<إِنَّكُمْ وَمَا تَعْبُدُونَ مِنْ دُونِ اللَّهِ حَصَبُ جَهَنَّمَ>> (Indeed, you and what you worship besides Allah are the fuel of Hell), which is darkness. Darkness is Hell (جهنم). What darkness and what Hell is greater than ignorance (الجهل)?

Allah likened it to darkness in His saying: <<أَوْ كَظُلُمَاتٍ>> (Or like layers of darkness), saying: <<ظُلُمَاتٌ بَعْضُهَا فَوْقَ بَعْضٍ>> (Darkness, one above the other). This is ignorance upon ignorance, which is the ignorance of one who is ignorant and does not know that he is ignorant. He negated that he could even *almost* see his hand, so how could he see it? The hand is mentioned here rather than anything else because it is the locus of the existence of Power (الاقتدار) and by it creation occurs. That is, if he extends his power to see it, he cannot almost see it due to the darkness of ignorance. If he saw it, he would see it as the very essence of Divine Power. Do you not see that when he extends it in the light, which is knowledge (العلم), he sees his hand, which is his power? Thus, he knows that cosmic power is the Power of the Real (اقتدار الحق), due to the removal of the accumulated darknesses, one above the other.

For this reason, the similitude was made with the most intense darknesses: the darkness of the atmosphere is coupled with the darkness of the sea, coupled with the darkness of the wave, coupled with the darkness of the piling up of waves, coupled with the darkness of the clouds that veil the lights of the stars. No light remains manifest, neither in its essence nor in any of its media of manifestation. The darkness of the night is the darkness of nature (الطبع). The darkness of the sea is the darkness of ignorance, which is the loss of knowledge. The darkness of thought is the darkness of the wave. The darkness of the piled-up waves is the darkness of the confusion of thoughts in ambiguities (الشبه). The darkness of the clouds is the darkness of disbelief (الكفر). Whoever combines these darknesses has suffered a manifest loss. This is the state of the Nullifiers (المعطلة) and no others.

### [The Science of Clarifying the Degrees of Divine Proximity from the Presence of the Tongue]

As for what this station contains concerning the science of clarifying the degrees of Divine Proximity (القرب الإلهي) from the Presence of the Tongue (حضرة اللسن): Know that this is the knowledge of the Lawgiver (الشارع) who translates for Allah, whom we are commanded to believe in regarding both the firm (محكمه) and the ambiguous (متشابهه) verses. We must accept everything he brought. If we claim certainty (قطع) about any part of that, believing it to be the exact intention of the Speaker (God) in reality, the rank of Faith (الإيمان) departs from us. For the intellectual proof (الدليل) rules over the good, thereby nullifying the ruling of Faith.

The sound knowledge (العلم الصحيح) comes from the believer who says to the proponent of this proof: "Your certainty that what your observation granted you is the intended meaning of the one who spoke it is the very essence of ignorance and the loss of sound knowledge, even if it coincides with knowledge. Faith has departed from you." Felicity (السعادة) is linked to Faith and to sound knowledge based on knowledge. Sound knowledge is that which remains accompanied by Faith.

The Gnostic (العارف) must clarify the path of felicity as a deputy for Allah the Exalted among His creation, like the moon acting as a deputy for the sun in delivering light. The Messengers (الأنبياء المرسلون), peace be upon them, are the translators (التراجمة) for the Real (الحق), and the inheritors are upon their degree by virtue of the understanding Allah grants them concerning what the Messengers brought of the Book and the Sunnah. This is the science of clarification in brief.

### [The Combination of Opposites in Divine Knowledge is the Cause of the Reconciliation of the Two Co-Wives]

As for the knowledge of the reconciliation of the two co-wives (الضرتين): Know that Abu Sa'id al-Kharraz was asked, "How did you know Allah?" He replied, "By His combining of opposites," and recited: <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ وَالْآخِرُ وَالظَّاهِرُ وَالْبَاطِنُ>> (He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Hidden). That is, He is the First who specified what is the Last, and the Manifest from the perspective of what is the Hidden, because the perspective (الحيثية) is one in His regard. Every two opposites are two co-wives.

This cannot be grasped by the power of the intellect (قوة العقل), for the power of the intellect does not grant it. Rather, this is grasped from the station beyond the sphere of the intellect (وراء طور العقل), which is the sphere that granted necessities their necessity, possibilities their possibility, impossibilities their impossibility, and Onenesses their oneness. It is He who made the one single, just as He made the necessary necessary by granting it necessity. The power of the intellect cannot grasp what we have mentioned through its thought. This is sound Divine knowledge (علم صحيح إلهي), not intellectual knowledge.

When the two opposites meet in Divine Knowledge, the two co-wives reconcile and love each other, since they belong to a single Essence (عين واحدة). Reflect upon this section with the light of Faith, not the light of the intellect, for it is intellectually rejected and unacceptable. Just as the power of sight cannot perceive intelligibles and does not exceed its limit, similarly, the intellect does not have the power to perceive what sight grants by itself without the mediation of sight. If the power of the intellect is incapable of independently knowing the visible things (المبصرات) as visible things—and both it and the power of sight are created—then how can it grasp what is beyond its sphere, toward what is higher in its relation to the Real, when it has failed to grasp what is beyond its sphere toward what is, in its estimation, a lower degree, namely the senses? Whoever needs a created being like himself in a matter is more in need of the Creator. This allusion is sufficient for what the Gnostics know of this.

### [Rapture (الاصطلام) is a Fire that Descends upon the Hearts of the Lovers, Burning Everything it Finds Except the Beloved]

As for the knowledge of the necessary Rapture (الاصطلام اللازم) and the description of those among the near ones (المقربين) who are granted this station of Rapture, as opposed to those like them who are not: Know that Rapture is a fire that descends upon the hearts of the lovers, burning everything it finds except the Beloved. At times, it removes the image of the Beloved from the lover's soul (نفس المحب). This is the moment when the lover seeks to imagine his Beloved but cannot, nor can he establish her form, due to the intense heat of the flame of love. In that state, he is called raptured (مصطلم). This is what the poet intended in his saying:

> Deposit burning in my heart, deposit
> Your essence, you are tormented within my ribs.

> Cast the arrows of love or withhold them,
> You are afflicted with what you cast, along with me.

> Its target is the heart, and you are the one
> Whose dwelling is in that very place.

From this state, Qays ibn al-Mulawwah, Majnun Layla, spoke. Layla came to him while he was raptured, taking ice and placing it on his chest, which immediately melted due to the heat of his heart. He was crying, "Layla! Layla!" seeking her because her image was lost from his imagination (خيال). She called out to him, "O Qays, I am your object of desire, I am Layla!" But he had no imagined form of her in his soul by which to recognize her. When he heard her name, he said to her, "Go away from me, for your love has distracted me from you."

This is the state of Rapture. It is a necessary characteristic of the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) and an effect of every Divine Name in which the Beauty of the Real (جمال الحق) is witnessed. It intervenes between the servant and the qualification (تكييف) of the Real, and it removes every form that the servant tries to fix or imagine. For this reason, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Persist in [saying] O Possessor of Majesty and Honor (يا ذا الجلال والإكرام)," meaning persistence (الإلظاظ). Majesty (الجلال) is never mentioned in the Prophetic sayings without Honor (الإكرام) accompanying it, so that the servant's form (رسم العبد) remains and is not utterly annihilated (يذهب بعينه).

The Majesty that is the Majesty of Beauty (جلال الجمال) clothes you with awe, so you revere the station. This is what the lover and the Gnostic find in themselves of the magnification of the Beloved, preferring His Presence over everything else. Allah's Honor (إكرام) to him is that He prefers Him over everything.

There is also a rapture that vanishes immediately, which is what descends upon the heart from witnessing the Beloved in the form of imagination. As long as this imagination lasts, the rapture lasts. Majesty (الجلال) erases this image from the soul out of jealousy of its being limited by a form, for He is the Absolute (الإطلاق). The rapture of that limited form vanishes with its removal.

The Necessary Rapture (الاصطلام اللازم) remains, which is the effect of Majesty in the soul. The lover sees himself rejecting the imagined form in his soul that says, "I am your Beloved," and turns away from it, magnifying his Beloved, lest he limit Him, knowing that his Beloved is not limited. For this reason, he burns within himself when he desires or wishes to fix what cannot be fixed, so that he may enjoy it.

For this reason, knowledge (العلم) is more noble than love, and by it Allah commanded His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to ask for increase in it, because it is the very essence of Divine Guardianship (الولاية الإلهية). By it, Allah takes charge of His servants, by it He honors them, and by it they know that He is unknowable. As for the lover who is not a Gnostic, he creates an image in his soul in which he wanders and which he loves. He has only worshipped and longed for what is under his own control. Nothing removes him from this station except Gnosis (المعرفة).

The bewilderment (حيرة) of the Gnostic concerning the Divine Presence is the greatest of bewilderments, because He is beyond confinement and limitation.

> The gazelles scattered upon Khidash,
> And Khidash knows not what he hunts.

He possesses all forms, yet no form limits Him. For this reason, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say: "O Allah, increase my bewilderment concerning You (اللهم زدني فيك تحيرا)." This is the highest station, the most manifest view, the nearest rank, the most radiant manifestation, and the most excellent path. From this Presence issued the warning, so stability ceased, and destruction descended upon the realm of the disbelievers. No veil or screen remains but is torn and rent by this most sublime witnessing. For the screen limits the screened, and the veil confines the veiled, and there is no limit to His Essence (ذاته) and no constraint to His Majesty (جلاله). How can anything conceal Him, or how can His Essence be absent? <<تَجْرِي بِأَعْيُنِنَا جَزَاءً لِمَنْ كَانَ كُفِرَ>> (Sailing under Our observation, a recompense for he who had been denied).

Whoever says: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him) has spoken the truth, because there is no existent whose Essence is not absent from Him, nor is He confined by a "where" (أين), except Allah. All sensory and spiritual forms are His manifestations. He is the Speaker from every form, not *in* every form. He is the One seen by every eye, and the One heard by every ear. He is the One whose speech was never heard so as to be comprehended, nor was He looked upon by sight so as to be limited, nor did He have a manifestation so as to be constrained. The "He" (الهو) is necessary for Him: <<لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ>> (There is no god but He, the Exalted in Might, the Wise). He erases (يَمْحُو), and He is the very essence of what He erases. He establishes (وَيُثْبِتُ), and He is the very essence of what He establishes. <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him) in this ruling. Sound, gifted knowledge (العلم الصحيح الموهوب) testifies to this.

The knowledge of intellectual proof (علم الدليل) negates Him, since it has no grasp of Him and is only concerned with the attributes of negation and transcendence (التنزيه). The knowledge of Unveiling (علم الكشف) affirms Him and maintains Him, and no manifestation appears to it but that it sees Him within it. Both knowledges are sound. He is for every perceptive power according to its capacity, so that it may know that it has not departed from its rank, and that it has attained no knowledge of Allah beyond what it is in itself. Its essence is known, and its soul is described. He departed from limitation and boundaries by His manifestation within them, so that He might be the Worshipped One. He decreed that none should be worshipped but Him. Thus, the idols and statues were manifestations for Him in the belief of the disbelievers, who applied the name of god to them. They worshipped none but the God (الإله) whom that manifestation indicated. He fulfilled their needs, gave them drink, and punished them when they did not respect that Divine Presence in that inanimate form. They are the wretched ones (الأشقياء), even if they were correct that they worshipped none but Allah. Look at this existential permeation (السريان الوجودي) in these manifestations, how some were made felicitous by it and others wretched.

Some said: "Everything you imagine in yourself or that your imagination forms, Allah is contrary to that." He spoke the truth and lied, manifested and veiled. Another said: "The Real is not indicated by proof, nor is He intelligible to the intellects. Intellects do not attain Him through their thoughts, nor do gnoses bring Him down through their remembrance. When He is remembered, it is by Him that one remembers, and by Him that one thinks and comprehends. He is the intellect of the rational, the thought of the thinkers, the remembrance of the rememberers, and the proof of the indicators. If He departed from anything, He would not be; and if He were contained in anything, He would not be."

I have clarified for you the effect of the Necessary Rapture, and that the scholars (العلماء) are the near ones (المقربون) who attained this most protected witnessing and this tremendous Gnosis. As for those besides them, a sign has been established for them which they worship, and a reality which they witness, which is what their belief encompasses, based on a proof established for them or their imitation of the proponent of a proof. In their own estimation, they have achieved their goal, devoted themselves to their worshipped object, found peace in it, and rested from bewilderment. They disbelieve in whatever contradicts what they hold, and they undoubtedly disbelieve others who hold a different belief. For this reason, some disbelieve others and some curse others, in this world and the Hereafter.

The realized scholar (العالم المحقق), knowing the reality of the matter, finds delight in his own essence and in the world, both its manifest and hidden aspects. He is the correct Essence (العين المصيبة) and the transcendent, stipulated similitude (المثل المنزه المنصوص عليه) which the Real negated from being likened or opposed in His saying: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). That is, there is nothing like the like of Him. The *kāf* (like) is the *kāf* of description; it is not superfluous, as some believe. Some scholars hold that even if a like were hypothesized for Him, that like would not be similar to Him, so how much more so is He Himself not similar? Others hold that it is the negation of the like from the verified similitude we mentioned.

Al-Junayd was asked about Gnosis (المعرفة) and the Gnostic (العارف). He said, "The color of the water is the color of its container." He affirmed the water and the container, thus affirming the letter and the meaning, and perception and negating perception. He separated and combined. How excellent was his saying!

Now that I have clarified the rank of the Necessary Rapture, let us clarify what remains of this station, which is the knowledge of Divine Generosity (الجود الإلهي) that is outside of obligation, and whether the Real can be an exchange attained through a specific deed or not.

### [Indeed, Allah Has Constrained Generosity and Absolute Generosity]

Know that Allah has Constrained Generosity (جود مقيد) and Absolute Generosity (جود مطلق). He the Glorious constrained some of His Generosity with obligation, saying: <<كَتَبَ رَبُّكُمْ عَلَى نَفْسِهِ الرَّحْمَةَ>> (Your Lord has prescribed mercy for Himself). That is, He obligated and imposed mercy upon Himself for a specific group characterized by a specific deed: <<مَنْ عَمِلَ مِنْكُمْ سُوءًا بِجَهَالَةٍ ثُمَّ تَابَ مِنْ بَعْدِهِ وَأَصْلَحَ فَأَنَّهُ غَفُورٌ رَحِيمٌ>> (Whoever among you does wrong out of ignorance and then repents after that and reforms—indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful). This is a constrained generosity (جود مقيد) by obligation for one who possesses this description, and it is an exchange (عوض) for this specific deed. However, the repentance and reform are themselves from Absolute Generosity (الجود المطلق). Thus, He attracted His Generosity by His Generosity. Nothing besides Him ruled over Him, nor did anything besides Him constrain Him.

The servant, between the two Generosities, is a vanishing accident and a subsisting accident. Sahl ibn Abdullah, our scholar and Imam, said: "I met Iblis, and I recognized him, and he recognized from me that I recognized him. A debate ensued between us. He spoke to me, and I spoke to him. The discussion escalated and the dispute lengthened until I stopped, and he stopped, and I was bewildered, and he was bewildered. The last thing he said to me was: 'O Sahl, Allah the Almighty says: <<وَرَحْمَتِي وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ>> (My mercy encompasses all things). This is general, and it is not hidden from you that I am a 'thing' without doubt, because the word 'all' necessitates encompassing and generality, and 'thing' is the most indefinite of indefinites. Therefore, His mercy has encompassed me.' Sahl said: 'By Allah, he silenced me and bewildered me with the subtlety of his presentation and his triumph with such a verse. He understood from it what we did not understand, and knew from it and its indication what we did not know. I remained bewildered and reflective, and I began reciting the verse to myself. When I reached His saying in it: <<فَسَأَكْتُبُهَا>> (I will prescribe it), I was delighted and imagined that I had triumphed with a proof and overcome him with what would break his back. I said to him: 'O accursed one, Allah has constrained it with specific descriptions that exclude it from that generality: <<فَسَأَكْتُبُهَا لِلَّذِينَ يَتَّقُونَ>> (I will prescribe it for those who fear Me).' Iblis smiled and said: 'O Sahl, I did not think that ignorance would reach this extent with you, nor did I think you were here. Do you not know, O Sahl, that constraint (التقييد) is your attribute, not His attribute?' Sahl said: 'I returned to myself, choked on my saliva, and the water stood in my throat. By Allah, I found no answer, nor did I close any door in his face. I knew that he had found a point of hope. He departed, and I departed. By Allah, I do not know what will happen after this, for Allah the Glorious did not stipulate what removes this ambiguity. The matter remains with me dependent on His Will (المشيئة) concerning His creation. I do not rule over Him in this matter with a limit that ends or a limit that does not end.'"

Know, O my brother, that I tracked the arguments narrated from Iblis, and I found no argument shorter than his, nor anyone more ignorant than him among the scholars. But when I came across this issue narrated from him by Sahl ibn Abdullah, I was astonished and knew that he possessed knowledge free from ignorance. He is Sahl's master in this issue. As for us, we took it only from Allah, so Iblis has no favor over us in this issue, praise be to Allah, nor in any other. I hope the same for the rest of our lives. This is a fundamental issue, not a secondary one.

Iblis awaits Allah's mercy to reach him from the very essence of Grace (المنة) and Absolute Generosity (الجود المطلق), by which He obligated upon Himself what He obligated, and by which He accepted the repentance and reform of those who repented. <<فَالْحُكْمُ لِلَّهِ الْعَلِيِّ الْكَبِيرِ>> (The ruling belongs to Allah, the Most High, the Grand), free from constraint in constraint. Nothing is obligatory upon Allah except what He obligated upon Himself.

The Gnostic (العارف) is likewise in his generosity: he is not constrained, and he does not give what is obligatory upon him, for the obligation of giving is caused by ownership (الملك), and the Gnostic has no ownership with Allah. The wealth in the Gnostic's hand belongs to Allah, not to him. Zakat (obligatory charity) is due on the essence of the wealth, upon the owner of the wealth, and there is no owner but Him, the Glorious. He obligated upon Himself to give a specific amount from this wealth, which is the right of a group of His creation, which He obligated for them upon Himself in this wealth held by the Gnostic. The Gnostic gives the right of that group from this wealth as a deputy for the Owner of the wealth, just as a guardian gives on behalf of an orphan by virtue of agency, for he is his guardian.

From this chapter, a group erred in their unveiling of this station, and they did not pay the Zakat on the wealth in their hands. I saw a group of them who gave more than the Zakat but did not pay Zakat, saying, "Allah the Exalted is not obligated to do anything, and this wealth belongs to Allah, not to me, and my hand in it is a loan." In this matter, I follow the Hanafi school: just as the guardian of an orphan is not obliged to pay Zakat on the orphan's wealth because the orphan is not obligated to pay Zakat, since he is the one addressed, I do not pay Zakat on it.

I have clarified for you, may Allah grant you success, Divine Generosity and its division.

As for whether the Real (الحق) can be an exchange (عوض) for a specific deed or not: Know that Malik ibn Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, said concerning a man who gives a gift to another, and the recipient does not reciprocate, so the giver demands recompense before the judge: The judge must clarify the matter for him, due to its ambiguity, so that the ruling can be based on specification. He asks him: "When you gave this gift, what did you seek by it? Did you seek recompense (جزاء) in Paradise, or exchange (معاوضة) in this world, or did you seek the Face of Allah (وجه الله)?" If the litigant says, "I sought reward in the Hereafter from Paradise, or exchange in this world," the judge rules against the recipient to return the essence of what he took, if the essence remains. If the essence is gone, he rules for the value, with disagreement on whether the value is considered at the time of giving or the time of judgment. If he says, "I only gave it seeking the Face of Allah," the judge rules nothing for him in that, saying, "Your companion does not possess what you sought with your gift."

From one perspective, [Malik] affirmed it as an exchange in what appears, for Malik did not explicitly state more than this. From another perspective, he negated it from being an exchange, for nothing among His creatures can match Him in measure, and everything is His grace. However, the exchange with Allah for this giver is in the Hereafter, with something commensurate with his gift. If He adds more than that, it is from the chapter of Grace (المنة). It has been said:

> For everything, if you depart from it, there is a substitute,
> But there is no substitute for Allah if you depart from Him.

The verification in this matter is that the Real (الحق), in terms of His Essence (ذاته) and Existence (وجوده), cannot be matched by anything, nor is it correct to desire or seek Him for His Essence. Rather, the seeker seeks and the desirer desires His Gnosis (معرفته), or His Witnessing (مشاهدته), or His Vision (رؤيته). All of this is *from* Him, not *Himself* (ليس هو عينه). Since it is from Him and not Him, it can be an exchange.

Thus, his deed in this world, which is the Presence with Allah in the saying: "Worship Allah as if you see Him,"

This deed's recompense (جزاؤه) with Allah is His Vision (رؤيته), which is the highest of stations. It is a recompense for the one who is present here in his deed, and it is an increase and grace (زيادة ومنة) for the one who is not present. Thus, for the latter, it is not an exchange, but for the former, it is an exchange.

The Presence in this world is from Absolute Generosity (الجود المطلق), from the very essence of Grace (عين المنة). The Vision is from Constrained Generosity (الجود المقيد), as a recompense for what He obligated upon Himself. From His Generosity, you witnessed His Generosity. Nothing departed from Him, nor did any creature obligate anything upon Him. <<لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ>> (There is no god but He, the Exalted in Might, the Wise).

If the servant gives to another initially, without that other deserving recompense, then this giver is under the constraint of the Real (الحق) because of that deserving. His giving, in this case, is not due to desert, and he seeks nothing by it but the Face of Allah, whether he seeks it by his intention or not. For the state of initial giving grants that, as he is characterized therein by the Attribute of the Real, which is Absolute Generosity, since his giving was not a recompense. Since this is his state, just as Allah the Exalted seeks recompense for the graces He bestowed upon His servants—which is gratitude (الشكر) for them and the knowledge that the graces are from Him—and He rewards that gratitude and that knowledge, similarly, this servant who bestows grace upon others initially is granted the freedom of the tongue of the recipient to thank and praise him. Then Allah takes charge of his recompense, not with Paradise, but by virtue of his being characterized by His Attribute through this giving.

I have clarified the possibilities contained within this station. <<وَاللَّهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way).
